analytic.title: Topological components of spaces of commuting elements in connected nilpotent Lie groups

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: We study the homotopy type of spaces of commuting elements in connected nilpotent Lie groups, via almost commuting elements in their Lie algebras. We give a necessary and sufficient condition on the fundamental group of such a Lie group G to ensure Hom(Z k , G) is pathconnected. In particular for the reduced upper unitriangular groups and the reduced generalized Heisenberg groups, Hom(Z k , G) is not path-connected, and we compute the homotopy type of its path-connected components in terms of Stiefel manifolds and the maximal torus of G.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The space Hom(Z k , G) of ordered commuting k-tuples in a Lie group G has been studied in various settings such as geometry, homotopy theory and mathematical physics -in large part because Hom(Z k , G) may be identified with the space of flat G-bundles over a rank k-torus. From the point of view of physics, the case of interest is when G is a compact Lie group, and from the homotopical point of view this may be justified by a remarkable result from A. Pettet and J. Souto [11] which states that for the group of complex or real points of a reductive algebraic group G (defined over R in the latter case), the inclusion K ֒→ G of its maximal compact subgroup induces a deformation retraction Hom(Z k , G) ≃ Hom(Z k , K). However, there are many Lie groups which are not algebraic where such a homotopy equivalence is far from achievable. For instance, W. Goldman [8] studied the space of commuting pairs in H 3 (R), the reduced Heisenberg group over R, and showed that Hom(Z 2 , H 3 (R)) has an infinite number of path-connected components, whereas the space of commuting pairs in S 1 ⊂ H 3 (R) is path-connected. Moreover, Goldman shows that at the level of path-connected components, the map that forgets the flat connection
div.formula: π 0 (Hom(Z k , G)) → [BZ k , BG] = H 2 (Z k ; π 1 (G)) ,
div.p: specialized to G = H 3 (R) and k = 2, is bijective. In this paper we will use this map to analyze the homotopy type of Hom(Z k , G) for connected nilpotent Lie groups, but from the Lie algebra perspective which is viable under these assumptions.

For a large class of nilpotent groups, we obtain a description of Hom(Z k , G) in terms of Stiefel manifolds and its maximal compact subgroup. Consider the group of n × n upper unitriangular matrices U n (F) over F, where F = R or C. We let A ⊂ U n (F) denote the standard central subgroup isomorphic to Z in the real case and to Z × Z in the complex case. Then we define the reduced group of n × n upper unitriangular matrices as U n (F) := U n (F)/A .

For n ≥ 2, the maximal compact subgroup K ⊂ U n (F) is in all real cases the central subgroup S 1 and in all complex cases the central subgroup S 1 × S 1 . In particular the space of commuting k-tuples of K is path-connected for every k ≥ 1. The situation for the ambient groups is quite different. Our first result concerns a complete identification of the homotopy type of Hom(Z k , U n (F)). For convenience we set D(R) := C and D(C) := H (the quaternions), so that we have a unified way to refer to them as D(F) -here D stands for the Cayley-Dickson doubling construction.

Theorem 1. Let k, n ≥ 1, and F = R or C. Then the map that forgets the flat structure at the level of path-connected components π 0 (Hom(Z k , U n+2 (F)) → H 2 (Z k ; A) is injective for every k ≥ 2, and surjective if and only if k 2 ≤ n. Moreover, each component parametrized by a class β ∈ H 2 (Z k ; A) is homotopy equivalent to
div.formula: V r (D(F) n ) × (S 1 ) k dim R F ,
div.p: where 2r = rank(β).

Here V q (D(F) m ) as usual stands for the Stiefel manifold of q-frames in D(F) m , and we think of a cohomology class β as an antisymmetric bilinear form over F k where rank(β) is the rank of its associated matrix with respect to the canonical basis of F k .

The generalized Heisenberg groups H 2n+1 (F), of dimension 2n+1 over F, are naturally subgroups of U n+2 (F) that contain the center, so we analogously define the reduced generalized Heisenberg group of dimension 2n + 1 as H 2n+1 (F) := H 2n+1 (F)/A .
Our theorem heavily relies on the fact that the inclusion (Proposition 2)
div.formula: Hom(Z k , H 2n+1 (F)) ≃ ֒− → Hom(Z k , U n+2 (F))
div.p: admits a deformation retraction. Then we show that, up to homotopy, the path-connected components of Hom(Z k , H 2n+1 (F)) correspond to symplectic frames of (F 2n , ω n ) where ω n is the symplectic form that determines H 2n+1 (F). In Subsection 3.3 we give an interesting application of Theorem 1 to classifying spaces for commutativity. We exhibit a connected Lie group G (infinite dimensional) whose looped commutator map splits, up to homotopy. Our approach to understand the homotopy type of commuting elements in a connected nilpotent Lie group G is via almost commuting elements in its Lie algebra g. These spaces are related by the Baker-Campbell-Hausdorff formula (see Proposition 1 for a precise statement). When G is simplyconnected and nilpotent we obtain that Hom(Z k , G) is contractible (Corollary 1), and hence it has the same homotopy type of the space of commuting elements in its maximal compact subgroup K = {1}, the trivial subgroup. If G is connected and nilpotent but with non-trivial π 1 (G), a deformation retraction to the subspace of commuting elements in its maximal compact subgroup may or may not exist depending on a condition on π 1 (G), when regarded as a discrete subgroup of the center of the Lie algebra Z(g), namely π 1 (G) ∼ = ker(exp | Z(g) ). We merge our results in Corollary 3 and Corollary 4 into the following theorem.

Theorem 2. Let G be a connected nilpotent Lie group and K ⊂ G a maximal compact subgroup. Then the inclusion Hom(Z k , K) ֒→ Hom(Z k , G) admits a deformation retraction if and only if no non-trivial element in π 1 (G) corresponds to a Lie bracket under the isomorphism
div.formula: π 1 (G) ∼ = ker(exp | Z(g) ).
div.p: As it is well known, for non-compact Lie groups G, the space of isomorphism classes of representations Rep(Z k , G) = Hom(Z k , G)/G in general does not behave nicely from the topological point of view, as it may not even be a T 1 -space. However, Theorem 1 still gives a full account on the indexing set of path-connected components for Rep(Z k , U n+2 (F)) by a standard argument of injective composites (see Corollary 5).

For H 2n+1 (F) we describe in detail, what comes into place when modding out by the conjugation action. For instance, it turns out the the representation space Rep(Z 2 , H 2n+1 (F)) contains the socalled irrational tori (see Example 1). It is not hard to believe then, that from the homotopical point of view, studying these moduli spaces as they stand may not be achievable. As an alternative, we compute the maximal Hausdorff quotient which we denote by Rep(Z k , H 2n+1 (F)) T2 , and show that the path-connected components parametrized by a form β ∈ H 2 (Z k , A) coincide with its maximal Hausdorff subspaces
div.formula: {f ∈ Hom(F k , F 2n ) | f * ω n = β}
div.p: (which have the homotopy type of V r (D(F) n ), where r = rank(β)), except for the path-connected component of the trivial representation, which up to homotopy is simply (S 1 ) k dim R F .

In the last part of the paper, from an independent interest, we study the space of 2n × k matrices whose columns span an isotropic subspace of F 2n with respect to the standard symplectic form. In our notation this space corresponds to X(k, n, 0). Our motivation is that X(k, n, 0) is very closely related to Hom(Z k , H 2n+1 (F)) 1 . We consider the filtration of X(k, n, 0) induced by the rank of a matrix. We found particularly interesting that the aforementioned filtration still carries homotopical information regarding the full space Hom(Z k , H 2n+1 (F)), at least up to a fiber sequence. We denote the strata of the rank filtration by X(k, n, 0) d , and then we have a smooth fiber bundle
div.formula: X(k, n, 0) d → Gr(d, F k )
div.p: with fibers the space of linear isotropic embeddings F d → F 2n , which we denote by Iso(2n, d, F). We show that Iso(2n, d, F) is homotopy equivalent to the Stiefel manifold V d (D(F) n ). The main result of this last section is a homotopy stable splitting of the strata X(k, n, 0) d into a wedge of Thom spaces following Crabb and Gonçalves [6]. The splitting is depicted in Theorem 5.

We start with some structural results for commuting elements in connected nilpotent Lie groups, which are completely deducted from almost commuting elements in its Lie algebra with respect to the Lie bracket.

div.head: Linearization of almost commuting elements in nilpotent Lie groups
div.p: Suppose G is a simply-connected nilpotent Lie group over R or over C, with Lie algebra g. It is well known that in this situation the exponential map exp : G → g is a diffeomorphism [9,Theorem 1.127]. Thus we may therefore assume that every element in G is of the form exp(x) for a unique x in g.
Lemma 1. Let G be a simply-connected nilpotent Lie group with Lie algebra g. Then the restriction exp | Z(g) : Z(g)
is an isomorphism of abelian groups.

Proof. By the exponential map properties, it is clear that the restriction of the exponential map to Z(g) is an injective homomorphism. Since exp is surjective we have exp(Z(g)) ⊂ Z(G). To see that exp | Z(g) surjects onto Z(G), first note that for every x, y ∈ g, the Baker-Campbell-Hausdorff formula (BCH) implies that [exp(x), exp(y)] = exp([x, y] + z),

where z is a finite linear combination of nested brackets in x and y, each of them of length at least 3. Suppose exp(x) ∈ Z(G). Then [exp(x), exp(y)] = 1 and thus [x, y] = −z. We may conclude that if L := x, y is the Lie subalgebra of g generated by x and y, then
div.formula: [x, y] ∈ [L, [L, L]], but since [x, y] generates [L, L] we further obtain that [L, [L, L]] = [L, L]
div.p: . Now L is a subalgebra of a nilpotent algebra which makes it also nilpotent, and then the previous equality implies [L, L] = 0. As this holds for any y ∈ g, it follows that x is central in g.
For a Lie algebra L, we may consider the space of almost commuting elements with respect to the Lie bracket. That is, for an abelian subgroup of the center of L, A ⊂ Z(L), we define
div.formula: B k (L, A) = {(x 1 , ..., x k ) ∈ L k : [x i , x j ] ∈ A for every i, j} .
div.p: Lemma 1 tells us that for any central subgroup A ⊂ Z(g) the exponential map is an A kequivariant diffeomorphism g k → G k where the A k -action on G k is the one induced by the isomorphism exp | Z(g) . This will allow us to stablish an easy dictionary from almost commuting tuples in Lie algebras to Lie groups.

div.p: Proof. Let K = exp(A). It suffices to show that under these hypotheses a bracket [x, y] ∈ A if and only if the commutator [exp(x), exp(y)] ∈ K.

First, let us assume that [x, y] ∈ A. Then BCH reads as exp(x) exp(y) = exp (x + y + [x, y]/2), and in particular [exp(x), exp(y)] = exp ([x, y]) ∈ K. Now suppose [exp(x), exp(y)] ∈ K. We already know that [exp(x), exp(y)] = exp([x, y] + z) where z is a finite combination of nested brackets in x and y, each of them of length at least 3, and by Lemma 1 it follows that [x, y] + z ∈ A. We now proceed similarly as in the proof of Lemma 1: let L := x, y be the Lie subalgebra of g generated by x and y. Applying the operators [x, −] and [y, −] to [x, y] + z we obtain that [x, [x, y]] and [y,

div.p: As L is nilpotent we further obtain that [L, L] is 2-step nilpotent. In particular all nested brackets in x and y of length at least 3 vanish, hence z = 0. It follows that exp([x, y]) ∈ K, as desired.
In particular we have a homeomorphism

div.p: Corollary 1. Let G be a simply-connected nilpotent Lie group. Then Hom(Z k , G) is contractible for every k.
Proof. Specializing Proposition 1 to A = {0}, on one side we obtain Hom(Z k , G) and on the other the space B k (g, {0}) which is star-convex, hence contractible.

Remark 1. Corollary 1 and the equivalence of categories between finite dimensional nilpotent Lie algebras and unipotent algebraic groups over a field of characteristic 0 [7, IV-Corollaire 4.5], expands on Pettet and Souto's deformation retraction, to include unipotent algebraic groups over R or C, as in all these algebraic groups the maximal compact subgroup of the group of complex or real points is the trivial subgroup.

Remark 2. A connected nilpotent Lie group can always be expressed as a quotient G/ exp(A), where G is a universal cover and A is a discrete central subgroup of g. Recall that the representation space Rep(Z k , G/ exp(A)) is the orbit space of Hom(Z k , G/ exp(A)) under the conjugation action of G/ exp(A), but since conjugation by elements of exp(A) is the identity, it is the same orbit space under the full conjugation action of G. div.p: Under this action the A k -equivariant homeomorphism of Proposition 1 becomes G-equivariant. Now, as A acts additively, G acts linearly over g and trivially over A, we conclude that the actions commute, so at the level of orbit spaces we have homeomorphisms

div.p: An immediate consequence of the linearity of the G-action over its Lie algebra g is that the contraction of Corollary 1 is preserved after taking quotients, as it is attained via a dilation. Hence Rep(Z k , G) is contractible, as well.
